newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: Cotton prices seen falling in India and Pakistan.
newsitem.headline: Cotton prices seen falling in India and Pakistan.

text.p: Cotton prices are likely to fall in India and Pakistan next week amid rising supply and weak demand, dealers said on Thursday.
Karachi prices rose this week prompted by higher world prices and demand for quality stocks from spinners fearing a shortfall, but some dealers said rates had now peaked.
Dealer Kishin Chand said prices could slip next week despite concern among spinners that supplies of good quality cotton may dry up after December 15, with imports looking costly.
"Spinners have already booked an estimated 125,000 480-lb bales, but most of the imported cotton will land in Pakistan after February," Chand said.
Dealers said high domestic prices had sidelined exporters while fresh arrivals would dampen demand from spinners.
Official rates were steady on Thursday. In the kerb market NIAB-78 traded at 2,225 rupees ($55.32) per maund (37.32 kg).

In India, increased new crop arrivals and limited buying by mills depressed prices this week, but dealers said expectations of a fresh export quota announcement could improve the mood.

"Lately there have been rumours that the government has allowed an additional 100,000 bales of cotton export to the Cotton Corporation of India," said Manubhai Amersey, a leading dealer. "We are awaiting confirmation from the government."
Daily crop arrivals in the Punjab region rose to 30-35,000 170-kg bales from 20-25,000 bales last week.

In spot deals, Bengal-deshi fell to 820-850 rupees per maund (37.32 kg) from 855-885 rupees. Punjab saw-ginned lost 40-60 rupees to 1,420-1,580. Gujarat Sankar-4 long-staple fell by 500 rupees to 17,500/18,500 rupees per candy (355.56 kg).
Leading exporter Chandubhai Thakkar predicted that the new cotton crop will reach only 15.4-15.6 million bales against an earlier estimate of 16.2-16.3 million bales.
"There is room for a further decline in prices but I expect the market to bottom out by the end of the calendar year," he said. "Market prices will start picking up again from January."
Amersey estimated the new crop at 15.70-15.80 million bales.
Traders said the government had allowed exports of 15,000 tonnes of cotton yarn last month and said they expected an additional export quota of about 10,000 tonnes this month.
